Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
Proposal Title: CAREER: Welfare Gains from Economic Integration: A Unified Approach
Proposal Number: SES - 1255298
Principal Investigator: Arkolakis, Konstantinos

The international trade field has seen a dramatic shift of its research agenda over the past decade. New evidence on the size advantage of exporters has motivated the modeling of firm heterogeneity, resulting in a new analytical framework for international trade. These changes in the field have also lead to a reconsideration of the old pressing question: how large are the gains from economic integration?

This proposal outlines a plan to advance the understanding of this question and to begin disseminating this work to the general public. The intellectual merit of the theoretical techniques suggested in this proposal derives from the fact that they maintain a tight link with the data. Thus, they deliver simple and analytically tractable relationships linking barriers to economic integration and openness and, in turn, openness and economic welfare. This theoretical work is complemented by careful quantitative policy analysis. The proposal is composed of four different research projects.

Previous assessments of the welfare gains from international trade focus on models with constant markups, thus ignoring the so-called pro-competitive effects of trade. The first project plans to develop a unified framework to analyze the pro-competitive effects of trade in models with variable markups. The main result implies that gains from trade are tightly associated with the degree of price pass-through of firms, a statistic measured independently by many economists.

The second project aims to offer a theoretical characterization of the impact of innovation on trade and welfare in a model with variable markups. The goal of this project is to understand the link between innovation and welfare and how pro-competitive effects shape this relationship. For this purpose, the project will assess how different assumptions on the demand and competition structure affect innovation and how trade can intensify innovation and affect welfare.

The third project develops an extension of a baseline trade framework that can seamlessly accommodate production of multinational firms and provide a new analytical tool for the understanding of the gains from multinational activity. A component of this project is the development and implementation of a procedure to estimate the model. The end product will be a useful tool for evaluating policies that reduce barriers to trade and multinational activity.

The final project will attempt to strengthen the tenuous link between dynamic open economy models and static trade models by developing a multi-country trade model that incorporates the fact that trade adjustment may take time. Using this framework as a basis the proposed project will study the dynamic adjustment of trade to macroeconomic shocks and the welfare implications of the sluggishness of trade responses to these shocks.

The proposed research will provide a framework to analyze the main forces that shape the gains from economic integration. It will also provide necessary tools to exploit the rich data on international trade and understand the workings of the world economy. Part of these tools will be integrated to the material of an undergraduate class in International Finance. The simple link between barriers to economic integration and economic welfare derived by this research agenda bypasses the various abstractions of economic theory and makes it a useful tool from a policy perspective. It is thus ideal material for the education of not only future economists but also policy makers and other future leaders in an interdependent world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of this CAREER proposal is to develop a unifying framework to analyze and characterize the welfare implications of removing barriers to openness. It contributes to the development of a new unified theory of the spatial economy to answer questions that have implications for academic researchers and policymakers alike. It integrates the recently developed models of heterogeneous firms, which examine decisions at the producer level, with spatial general equilibrium models, which capture the interactions of regions and countries across space. 

Three projects have been completed under this proposal.

First, the project  'Trade and the Topography of the Spatial Economy', (T. Allen and C. Arkolakis), published in Quarterly Journal of Economics, 2014. This project integrates a general equilibrium spatial model with an economic geography setup to understand the implications of geography for the determination of economic outcomes. The impact of investments in the infrastructure network, and particular the Interstate Highway System, on welfare, worker mobility and inequality across space are analyzed.

Second, the project 'On the Elusive Pro-Competitive Gains from Trade' (C. Arkolakis, A. Costinot, D. Donaldson, A. Rodriguez-Clare) forthcoming in the Review of Economic Studies. The paper develops a unified framework to analyze the welfare properties of trade models with variable price markups. While characterizing welfare gains in the presence of markup has been an elusive goal, the paper achieves so by illustrating that their contribution can be summarized by a simple statistic: the degree to which cost increases pass on firm prices. 

Third, the project  'Innovation and Production in the Global Economy'  C. Arkolakis, N. Ramondo, A. Rodriguez-Clare, and S. Yeaple), forthcoming in the American Economic Review. It develops a model of multinational production, where firms can move their production techniques and produce their goods in foreign countries. It studies how a variety of policies affect multinational relocation and innovation and can reshape the specialization of workers on those activities. It also evaluates how major events such as Brexit or the manufacturing rise of China can affect the inequality and the welfare gains from production integration.

These three papers serve a central aim of this proposal: to develop a unified framework to assess the welfare gains in models with space. To further this agenda, in work with S. Kortum the principal investigator incorporates a marketing cost mechanism in a dynamic model of the open macroeconomy to understand the slow market penetration of trade and the long run adjustment to trade liberalization.

Intellectual merit  

The proposed research will provide a framework to analyze the main forces that shape the static and dynamic gains from economic integration. The four main projects all serve the purpose of this and provide the necessary tools to exploit the rich data on international trade and multinational activity for understanding the workings of the world economy. The principal investigator has already started integrating part of his findings to the material of an undergraduate class in International Finance and Spatial Economics.

Broader of impacts 

The simple link between costs of economic integration and economic welfare promoted by this research agenda bypasses the various abstractions of economic theory and makes it a useful tool from a policy perspective. Thus, the tractable and intuitive results obtained in this research agenda make it an ideal material for the education of not only future economists but also policymakers and other future leaders in an interdependent world.
